strings.Value: "What is this place?"
"I'm looking for someone. Can you help me?"
"Do you let everyone into your house?"
"A cultist of Lamashtu is hiding in your lodge. I have to find them."
"Do you remember when they came to your lodge at least?"
"I'd like to examine your room, Dumra."
"How long have you been living here?"
"This place is rather secluded for a traveler's inn..."
"What is the main hunter's prey in these parts?"
"Listen… the sooner I cross you out of the suspect list, the sooner I'll leave you alone. Do me a favor and give me your room key, and all this will be over before you know it."
"I'm not going to ask twice, dammit! Put that key on a table now, or you'll regret talking back to your {mf|baron|baroness}!"
"We'll return to this question later."
"I'd like to see your wares."
"I have to go."
"I'd like to spend a night here."
"Let's go back to my other questions..."
"A crime has happened, Dumra. I need your help to find the culprit."
"Do you know who your guests are?"
"There are footprints leading to your lodge..."
"Your lodge is the only house in the neighborhood..."
"Several hours walk from your lodge is a shrine of Lamashtu..."
"I'm not going to argue with you."
"I don't like your tone, Dumra."
"Your guests, Dumra. Do you allow anyone who asks to spend a night here?"
"I meant that followers of Lamashtu prefer… let's say… free relationships."
"Poor choice of words. Forget what I said."
"You're suspiciously stubborn in your refusal to help..."
"How many people are there in the lodge now, except for you?"
"People say you came to the hall last..."
"That's enough about your lodge."
[Pay for the room]
"I have changed my mind."
"Seven gold pieces?! I am a ruler of these lands — shouldn't I rest here without paying?"
[Pay for the room]
"I see you had some hellknights as guests..."

{n}The woman looks at you with caution, throwing quick glances towards your companions.{/n} "Your Grace..."{n} She chooses the words carefully.{/n} "What an unexpected visit. I am the hostess of this place, my name is Dumra. How can I help you at this hour?"
"Yes?"
{n}Dumra looks at you without a word.{/n}
{n}A sturdy, dour-faced dwarf stands before you, hands on her hips. Despite the wrinkles on her face, she looks more than capable of handling herself.{/n}
"Can't you see for yourself?" {n}Dumra grumbles.{/n} "A place where people can rest after the hunt, enjoy a tankard or two, and fill their gullet. The nearest tavern is far, you know."
{n}Dumra hands tighten to fists, but she keeps them on her hips. She says nothing, merely stares at you defiantly.{/n}

{n}Dumra is silent for a moment, then nods and pulls an old, age-darkened key from her belt. {/n} "Your way then." Her eyes narrow. "But, have a care... no digging through my undergarments, or I'll have your hands on hooks, you hear?"

{n}Dumra grunts, then her eyes narrow.{/n} "Let's say I give you the key, and you use it to pin something incrim... increm... something bad on me! I won't allow it! Search the lodge up and down if you want, but stay out of my room!"
{n}Dumra glares at you for several moments, then finally grunts and pulls forth an old, age-darkened key from her belt. {/n} "Have it your way... {mf|baron|baroness}."

"That's how it goes..." {n}Dumra squints.{/n} "If anything is against your liking, you just start shaking your fists and rattling your weapons. Won't work with me! I'm under {g|Erastil}Erastil's{/g} protection, Your Grace, and the Great Hunter will not let anyone harm me!"
"Can I leave now?"

{n}Dumra stares at you for a moment, then utters a hoarse chuckle.{/n} "One of {g|Lamashtu}Lamashtu's{/g} own? That's quite a story you've spun, Your Grace. Next you'll tell me I'm holding {g|Rovagug}Rovagug{/g} down in the cellar? And what's your proof that I hide cultists?"
{n}Dumra's face turns red.{/n} "What are you hinting at, huh?"
{n}Dumra squints at you, searching your features.{/n} "Many years now. I know the whole neighborhood — flatlands and the swamps."
"This is not an inn." {n}Dumra looks around the room.{/n} "It's my home. I hunt for a living and let other fellow hunters spend a night here, if they find themselves too far from a tract."
"On the flatlands they go for fox and deer, birds in the swamp. There's always a chance of running into something more dangerous, of course."
{n}Dumra closes her eyes, trying to recall.{/n} "I went to check on my traps… some people arrived when I was away. So I can't tell you for sure, Your Grace."
"What else haven't I told you?"
{n}A sturdy, dour-faced dwarf stands before you, hands on her hips. Despite the wrinkles on her face, she looks more than capable of handling herself.{/n}

{n}She eyes you up and down.{/n} "First time here, is it? House rules are simple — don't trouble the other guests, clean up your own mess, and don't cross me, or the sky'll be your roof. Name's Dumra — but don't call me if you need anything, guests attend to themselves."

"So what did this culprit do wrong?" {n}Dumra's voice becomes thick, corners of her mouth curve down.{/n} "Shot a deer in someone's lands? And now the criminal has to run away as if she was an animal herself… Whatever it is, leave me out of it."
{n}Dumra crosses her arms and lifts her chin.{/n}
"So what? Folk come to this lodge everyday — both from the flatlands and the swamps."
"And?" {n}She lifts her chin.{/n} "Is it a bad thing — to provide shelter for those who's lost?"

"{mf|Baron|Baroness}, enough!" {n}The dwarf clasps her hands.{/n} "Here in the {g|Stolen Lands}Stolen Lands{/g} you can't swing a dead cat without hitting some goblin's nest, or cursed ruins, or a shrine of something foul!"

"Really." {n}The dwarf frowns, her eyes narrowing.{/n} "And how would you react, if a mob barged into your home and started troubling you and your guests? If you were expecting me to bow and scrape before you, then you're mistaken!"
{n}Dumra glares at you and mutters something under her breath.{/n}

{n}Dumra straightens and inhales slowly, a snarl rattling in her throat.{/n} "You know what? You may be a {mf|baron|baroness}, but I'm not going to listen to your filth!" {n}She spits on the counter — then almost out of habit, she immediately begins cleaning the surface with a rag. {/n} "What has my life come to when one such as you brands me as one of ill-repute?!"

{n}Dumra blinks several times, pondering your words. {/n} "Of course, everyone. What else am I expected I do — pick who gets a warm spot near the fireplace and who gets left out in the rain? I've let in you and your thugs, though you've put a terror in my other guests."
{n}Dumra shakes her head slowly.{/n} "You may think whatever you like." {n}She frowns.{/n} "As for me, I just don't like those who feel the need to meddle in the business of others."

"Watch yourself — there are three of them, all sitting over there." {n}Dumra nods towards her guests.{/n} "That one in the kitchen, guessing she's the servant to these two noble folk — they look to be carrying all the coin."

{n}Dumra looks at you closely for a moment, then grunts.{/n} "Right." {n}She speaks slowly, as if keeping her temper.{/n} "I went out to the kitchen when this clumsy gal has knocked over some of my pots. What of it?"
"You need something else?"
{n}Dumra doesn't change her expression.{/n} "Seven gold pieces."
{n}Dumra chews her lip, then answers with reluctance:{/n} "All right. Here is your key."
{n}Dumra narrows her eyes:{/n} "Ten gold pieces then."
{n}Dumra doesn't change her expression.{/n} "Ten gold pieces."
{n}Dumra chuckles but says nothing.{/n}
"Here is the key. Good night."
"Excuse me? Who're you calling a thug?!"
{n}Dumra eyes Octavia and falls silent, then shrugs.{/n} "You're a fair lass, sure, but who knows what thoughts you have in that pretty head of yours?"
"Here we go. Do you know how many times I've heard such words in the Iadaran court? As a side note, most of those speaking them turned out to be guilty."
{n}Dumra waves dismissively.{/n} "Ah, blast the snots back to Hell. They scare simple folk away just sitting there. Good thing you've shown them what's what."
{n}Dumra gives you a sullen glance. It seems she's not too happy to talk with you, but she doesn't dare refuse it openly.{/n}
"Why should I?" {n}Dumra tilts her head, her eyes appraising you.{/n} "I'm not their ward. They come, they pay for a bed, they keep quiet. Why would I care who they are?"
